title: Consumer spending rebound boosts American Express earnings
text:
American Express revenues jumped in the second quarter on the back of a rebound in consumer spending, ending a five-quarter run of declines for the credit card issuer.

Revenue rose 33 per cent to $10.2bn from $7.7bn a year earlier, coming in ahead of analysts' forecasts for $9.6bn, according to a consensus data compiled by Bloomberg. 

The rise underscores the recent recovery in consumer spending, following several months when customers paying down debt and closing accounts exceeded new sign-ups. 

“We saw card member spending accelerate from the prior quarter and exceed pre-pandemic levels in June, with the largest portion of this spending growth coming from Millennial, Gen Z, and small business customers,” said Stephen Squeri, Amex chair and chief executive. 

Credit card companies are spending heavily to lure new customers in the hope that they turn into borrowers once they whittle down the savings cushions built up during the pandemic.

Amex's marketing expenses rose 63 per cent in the quarter ahead of the launch of its US consumer Platinum Card, which the company says offers improved lifestyle and travel benefits.  

Discover Financial Services, which reported earnings earlier this week, said a 36 per cent increase in marketing contributed to a 26 per cent rise in new accounts over 2019 levels in the most recent quarter. Average credit card loans still fell 7 per cent.

Top US lenders, including JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup and Bank of America, have each unveiled new credit cards with enhanced rewards like souped-up cashback offerings in recent months in an effort to jump start growth. But analysts expect those promotions to be reined in before long.

“I do think some of the rewards products out there will not be sustainable long-term,” Discover chief executive Roger Hochschild warned. 

Overall, Amex reported second quarter net income of $2.3bn, up from $257m a year ago. This was boosted by the release of $866m in releases of reserves for potential bad loans.

Amex's stock was up 3.3 per cent in pre-market trading.
